thread.title: The most important 'Gilmore Girls' episodes - Business Insider
thread.title_full: The most important 'Gilmore Girls' episodes - Business Insider

posts.author: Kevin O'Keeffe
posts.title: The most important 'Gilmore Girls' episodes - Business Insider
posts.text:
• With a revival hitting Netflix soon, here's a trip down Gilmore Girls memory lane. • Here are the best Gilmore Girls episodes from every season of the show. 

\In its original run on the WB (and the CW for its last season), Gilmore Girls ran for seven seasons, each including 20-plus episodes. That is a lot of Gilmore Girls ! It's particularly a lot if you haven't watched but you want to catch up before the Netflix revival Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life hits the streaming service. 
What is a would-be Gilmore Girls fan to do if they want to relive the magic but can't commit the next two weeks of their lives to doing it? We've got a solution for you to catch up with mom Lorelai Gilmore, daughter Rory and their band of pals in the Connecticut town of Stars Hollow. 
We've reduced the 153-episode series to just 44 episodes — basically two seasons of TV. That's nothing! That's one weekend of binging, plus a few weeknights. It's easily doable before Nov. 25. 
Here's our breakdown of which episodes to watch and why. Season one Warner Bros 
Start with the pilot , because it sets up the series' core relationships well: Lorelai and Rory, their friends Sookie, Luke, Lane and Michel, etc. Then skip to "Rory's Dance" and "Forgiveness and Stuff," which work as a two-parter. Those nicely set up Dean as Rory's new boyfriend, as well as further establish the dynamic between Lorelai and her parents, Emily and Richard. 
Then skip to "Christopher Returns," which introduces Rory's father, Christopher. You can actually skip the rest of this season and the beginning of the next — it's mostly about Lorelai's relationship with Max Medina, a character who isn't returning for the revival. Plus, Rory and Dean break up, but they quickly get back together. Season two Warner Bros 
After skipping the first few episodes of the new season, pick up with "Nick & Nora/Sid & Nancy," which introduces vital new character Jess. Then jump to "The Ins and Outs of Inns," which introduces a major story that picks up in season four. "Richard in Stars Hollow" isn't a deeply necessary episode, but considering Richard's memory is going to play into a lot of A Year in the Life after actor Edward Herrmann's death, it's good to get to know him more. 
"It Should've Been Lorelai" comes next, giving more context to Christopher and Lorelai's relationship. Follow up with a triple play: "Teach Me Tonight," "Help Wanted" and "I Can't Get Started." It's a tall order to watch three in a row, but there's a continuous story that involves Rory, Jess, Luke and Lorelai that threads these episodes together. (Skip "Lorelai's Graduation Day," which is a sweet but ultimately frustrating installment.) Season three Warner Bros 
Watching the premiere, "Those Lazy-Hazy-Crazy Days," is necessary, as it sets the table for the rest of the season. Then skip to "They Shoot Gilmores, Don't They?" — which changes the landscape of the series pretty dramatically — followed by flashback episode "Dear Emily and Richard." That one is particularly important: It serves as Lorelai Gilmore's origin story. 
"The Big One" and "Keg! Max!" aren't a two-parter, but they do work well together. Unfortunately, they both involve Max Medina, but Rory's stories are vital. Wrap it up with the finale, "Those Are Strings, Pinocchio," in which Rory graduates and the two Gilmore girls decide their future. Season four Warner Bros 
The premiere is a fun but kind of pointless installment, so skip to "The Lorelais' First Day at Yale" instead. (The title is both a spoiler and very indicative of the episode itself.) We skipped a couple of important Dean episodes in season three, so watch "Chicken or Beef?" to get caught up on what's happening with him. 
Now, the rest of the season is pretty vital, so bear with us. Start with "A Family Matter" and "Nag Hammadi Is Where They Found the Gnostic Gospels," which bring back Jess for a two-episode arc. Then jump to "Luke Can See Her Face" and "Last Week Fights, This Week Tights" — again, Jess episodes, but they also have major Lorelai developments. 
The season four finale, "Raincoats and Recipes," is indeed required viewing, but we'd recommend watching it at the same time as the season five premiere. Season five Warner Bros 
Pair the season four finale with "Say Goodbye to Daisy Miller" and "A Messenger, Nothing More." Those three episodes feature perhaps the most significant change to Lorelai and Rory's relationship, one the show never really reverts. They also include Lorelai opening a new business and starting a new potential relationship, a change in Richard and Emily's dynamic and more. 
"You Jump, I Jump, Jack" and "The Party's Over" serve as a two-part exit for Rory's love interest and an introduction to Logan, Rory's third and final boyfriend. "Come Home" and "Wedding Bell Blues" make for a good Emily- and Richard-heavy night of Gilmore . "So... Good Talk" resolves the Lorelai story that starts in "Wedding Bell Blues," so watch that quickly too. 
"But I'm a Gilmore!" is a good standalone to check in on Rory's progress as a character. It's needed for our final two episodes of the season, "Blame Booze and Melville" and "A House Is Not a Home." Season six Warner Bros 
The first half of season six is deeply unpleasant to watch. It's still Gilmore Girls , so it's still good, but the Lorelai-Rory dynamic is never worse than in these installments. Watch "New and Improved Lorelai," then "We've Got Magic To Do." Then jump to a double feature of "Let Me Hear Your Balalaikas Ringing Out" and "The Prodigal Daughter Returns" to put the difficult plot to bed. 
To avoid spoiling you, we'll just say of the rest of the season that "Friday Night's Alright for Fighting" is one of the best episodes of the series, and a crucial one. "You've Been Gilmored" is a good episode to pair it with, if you're in the mood for two. Jump then to "Driving Miss Gilmore," following it up with the season finale, "Partings." Season seven The CW 
Season seven was not written or produced by series creator Amy Sherman-Palladino, so take it with a grain of salt. She's returning for A Year in the Life and has never watched this season in full . It's likely to impact the new season very little. 
Jump ahead to "To Whom It May Concern." You'll be very confused by some stuff happening, but look up recaps online instead. We're down to the last few episodes here, and we need to make up time. "I'd Rather Be in Philadelphia" is the last plot-vital episode of the series, featuring one relationship dissolving and another major development for Richard. 
Wrap it up with the series finale, "Bon Voyage" — and then bask in the glory of your triumph. Now, all there is to do is wait for A Year in the Life . Read the original article on Mic . Copyright 2016. Follow Mic on Twitter . More from Mic:

posts.title: Will there be a second season of The Crown on Netflix?
posts.text:
Will there be a second season of The Crown on Netflix? Will Claire Foy and Matt Smith's royal Netflix drama be back? ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW 
By Sarah Doran Sunday 13 November 2016 at 8:14AM 
Netflix drama The Crown only covers the first few years of Queen Elizabeth II's (Claire Foy) reign so surely there's room for a second series? 
The good news is, YES, there is indeed. A second series is already on order at Netflix, and is already in pre-production. Will Claire Foy and Matt Smith be back for a second series of The Crown? 
They've confirmed that they won't play The Queen and Prince Philip forever, but Foy and Smith can confirm they'll be back for series 2. 
In fact, they're already in rehearsals for another 8 month shoot - at least that's what they told RadioTimes.com at a recent Netflix event in New York. How many episodes will there be in The Crown series 2? 
Producer Andrew Eaton says we can probably look forward to another 10 episodes of royal drama from Peter Morgan's pen. When will The Crown be back for series 2? 
A launch date on Netflix has yet to be confirmed but watch this space - we'll keep you posted. 
The Crown is available to stream on Netflix now

thread.title: Is Bones Leaving Netflix in December 2016?
thread.title_full: Is Bones Leaving Netflix in December 2016?

posts.author: Kasey Moore
posts.title: Is Bones Leaving Netflix in December 2016?
posts.text:
What's on Netflix > News > Is Bones Leaving Netflix in December 2016? Is Bones Leaving Netflix in December 2016? Tweet 
Bones according to some Netflix users looks like it may be departing Netflix in December 2016 but only some seasons are and on different dates. Below, we’ll take a look as to what’s going on, whether it will expire and will keep it updated as we learn more. 
What’s going on then? As of right now, a select few are having notifications pushed through to them if they have Bones in their queue list. It notes that different seasons of Bones are scheduled to leave Netflix in December 2016. 
Bones is a crime drama produced by Fox and is about to go into its twelve season in January meaning the series is one of the longest running shows currently (excluding its animated selection) on Fox. 
Here’s what seasons are set to expire in addition to their dates: December 3rd – Bones – Season 5 (2009) December 7th – Bones – Season 7 (2011) December 9th – Bones – Season 6 (2010) What’s going on and will it expire? 
At the moment it’s hard to know exactly what’s going on. In most cases, when shows leave Netflix they do so in their entirety on a select date. For some animated sitcoms, old seasons are taken off in place for a brand new season. Those that come to our website regularly will know that season 11 was only just recently added in September. 
At this point, only some devices are reporting the show expiring with the main desktop website not showing an expiration date on the details page like it normally would. Therefore we’re going to call this a glitch for now but keep a close eye on it as we suspect more expiration dates may be added for the other seasons soon. 
For the moment, keep an eye on this page as well as our official leaving soon list for December 2016 where we’ll update you with the latest as soon as we know it. 
Are you seeing Bones expiring on your Netflix? Let us know in the comments below. Also on What's on Netflix Subscribe to our newsletter

thread.title: Chelsea Handler Breaks Down While Discussing Donald Trump Victory
thread.title_full: Chelsea Handler Breaks Down While Discussing Donald Trump Victory

posts.author: Lawrence Yee
posts.title: Chelsea Handler Breaks Down While Discussing Donald Trump Victory
posts.text:
Chelsea Handler fought back tears several times during her Netflix talk show while discussing the outcome of Tuesday’s presidential election.
The host was emotional right from the top of her show.
“Like a lot of people in this country, I’m sad. I’m disappointed, and I’m confused. But if Hillary [Clinton] can make it through a concession speech , then I can make it through a stupid television show,” Handler said.
She was later joined by Senator Barbara Boxer (D-Calif.) who also expressed her disappointment over Donald Trump’s victory . “My heart’s on the floor,” Boxer said. “I have learned how painful politics can be. But that doesn’t mean you run away. It means you pick yourself up, as the president said, and you fight even harder for your country, because it’s ours. It’s ours.”
When asked if she had spoken to Clinton since the results, Boxer said she hadn’t. “No, I did not want to speak to her at this point,” Boxer said. “I like to write,” she explained emotionally. “I have too much to say. I want to think about it.”
“I know as a woman, it feels so sexist,” Handler responded, beginning to cry. “I guess the message that I want to spread out to other women is to not give up — sorry, I hate f–king crying on camera — because this is so important. It’s easy to throw in the towel and say that we’re gonna leave, or I’m gonna move to Spain. Because I want to move to Spain, I really, really want to move to Spain right now. And everyone in my office is like ‘you have a responsibility. You have a voice and you have to use it and you have to be here.'”
Handler continued, “If you’re caught lying on camera three times in a row, if you’re referring to a woman’s genitalia. Those are non-presidential things …unpresidential things.”
The segment ended on a hopeful note, with Boxer praising the women who won Senate seats, including Kamala Harris, who is replacing her.
Handler later reiterated her stance, posting another video on Instagram Thursday morning.
Instagram Photo More
“I’m not leaving the country, Handler said defiantly. “This is my announcement. I’m going to keep fighting. For Hillary Clinton. In honor of Hillary Clinton.”

thread.title: Dave Chappelle And Kate McKinnon Lead The Way In A Memorable, Post-Election Episode Of ‘SNL’ | Decider | Where To Stream Movies & Shows on Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Instant, HBO Go
thread.title_full: Dave Chappelle And Kate McKinnon Lead The Way In A Memorable, Post-Election Episode Of ‘SNL’ | Decider | Where To Stream Movies & Shows on Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Instant, HBO Go

posts.author: Larry Getlen
posts.title: Dave Chappelle And Kate McKinnon Lead The Way In A Memorable, Post-Election Episode Of ‘SNL’ | Decider | Where To Stream Movies & Shows on Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Instant, HBO Go
posts.text:
+ More Options Powered by 
In the first episode following 9/11, Saturday Night Live didn’t bother trying to be funny right out of the gate, but instead asked Paul Simon to sing “The Boxer” as a tribute to New York’s first responders. 
Understanding the challenge of ushering in laughs related to this week’s election, the show took a similar approach, finding the perfect note for addressing the week while saluting a fallen icon in the process. 
The cold open instead featured Kate McKinnon as Hillary Clinton, sitting at a piano, playing and singing “Hallelujah,” which was written by Leonard Cohen, who died this week at age 82 . RELATED: ALEC BALDWIN IS A NO SHOW AT ‘SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE’, BACKS DOWN FROM DONALD TRUMP 
Given McKinnon’s deep well of talent, it’s little surprise she can sing and play piano as well. Hearing her, as Hillary, sing lines like, “I did my best, it wasn’t much,” and, “I’ve told the truth, I didn’t come to fool you,” resonated eerily with the circumstances. The song ends, “And even though it all went wrong/I’ll stand before the Lord of Song/With nothing on my tongue but Hallelujah.” McKinnon/Clinton turned to camera at song’s end and said, “I’m not giving up, and neither should you.” All in all, a fitting tribute to Cohen and Clinton, and a perfect elegy for what feels like the end of an era. 
But the show wasn’t done wowing us with its reaction to the election. By perfect coincidence, Dave Chappelle was this week’s host, and given the election’s surprising results and an aftermath that has seen a rise in harassment and violent racially- and sexually-motivated attacks, the never-mincing-words Chappelle couldn’t have been a better choice. The end result was one of the best cold open/monologue combinations in the show’s history. 
In his monologue, Chappelle talked about his lack of surprise at Trump’s victory, since, he says, “I know the whites,” and said that, “We elected an internet troll as our president.” He talked about the rash of shootings of black people in recent years and about Black Lives Matter, admitting it wasn’t the best slogan but saying that “You deserve a break today” was already taken. 
Talking about this week’s meeting at the White House between Trump and President Obama, he imagined Trump mentioning how hard the job looked, and Obama replying, “At least you get to be white while you’re doing it.” 
After praising Obama (possibly to repute reports from this week that had him insulting Obama and praising Trump), he took a semi-serious turn, mention that he’d been at a party at the White House just a few weeks ago. The party was sponsored by BET, so everyone there was black, “except for Bradley Cooper, for some reason.” He talked about the history of black people being allowed into the White House (hint: historically, it’s brief), and talked of how the event made him feel hopeful and proud to be an American. He ended by saying, “In that spirit, I’m wishing Donald Trump luck, and I’m gonna give him a chance, and we the historically disenfranchised demand that he give us one too.” 
The first sketch depicted a group of friends, all white expect for Chappelle, watching Tuesday night’s election results come in. The sketch was another chance for Chappelle to express a stark lack of surprise at the depth of the country’s racism, in contrast to his white friends, who are stunned that the country would elect Trump in light of his comments on minorities. The sketch was a shot at short-sighted liberal platitudes, as when Beck Bennett, reacting to news that Trump won Kentucky, says, “Well of course he won Kentucky. I mean, that’s where all the racists are.” Chappelle’s eye roll quickly told us, no. They’re everywhere. 
Chris Rock joined the sketch in the middle, and while the pace slackened – the hug he and Chappelle shared when he walked on stage seemed like a breaking of character, and the timing from here on felt like the pair just dropped into the Comedy Cellar for a loose set – the pair, as new state results came in, regarded their panicked white friends with almost joking disdain, mocking the naiveté of believing American citizens were too decent to elect Trump. As the realization kicks in, Cecily Strong says, “Oh my god. I think America is racist.” Chappelle answers, “Oh my god. You know, my great-grandfather told me something like that. But he was, like, a slave, so, I don’t know.” 
The show took a break from politics for an all-Chappelle extravaganza, as he parodied the controversial season opener of The Walking Dead by playing Negan, the show’s vicious new villain, and replacing the show’s cast, as Negan’s victims, with characters from his late lamented Chappelle’s Show , including Lil Jon, crack addict Tyrone Biggums, his pimp from the “Playa Haters Ball,” and Clayton Bigsby, the black white-supremacist, now a Trump voter in a “Make America Great Again” cap. 
On “Weekend Update,” co-hosts Colin Jost and Michael Che did what they’ve come to do, with each going into a series of short, loose, alternating monologues to start, commenting on the week’s events. While there were a few funny lines within – Che lead off by noting that Trump was elected President of the United States, then scoffed at the word “United”– the format fails to accomplish what it seems to be shooting for, which is adding an authoritative tone to the proceedings. 
Still, Jost had several solid lines, such as, over a photo of Obama and Trump shaking hands at the White House, “On Thursday, Trump went to the White House, and showed us how brave he is, by meeting face to face with the man who founded ISIS,” a reference to Trump’s accusation during the campaign that Obama founded ISIS. 
The segment then found McKinnon returning as Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, lamenting how she can’t retire now that Trump’s been elected, and consuming Emergen-C by the bag load as she dispenses her trademark Ginsburns. “The [Supreme Court] bench is now my porch. I’m gonna sit on it all day and scream, ‘No. Get out of my yard!'” 
McKinnon, who is gay, took special delight in razzing Vice President-elect Mike Pence, who believes in conversion therapy for homosexuals. Noting his resemblance to “the neighbor who kisses Kevin Spacey in American Beauty ,” she said, “Hey Mike Pence, sorry you looked at Magnum P.I. once and got a quarter chub and you’ve been haunted by it ever since. And that’s a gay Ginsburn.” She ended by noting that her burden could be lifted if Obama appointed Merrick Garland to the Supreme Court by recess appointment. 
The next sketch was a fourth-wall breaker. At first, the sketch, about restaurant employees using too much hair spray, seemed like a disaster, with Leslie Jones failing miserably to find her cue cards in time. But the incompetence, it turned out, was intended, as the sketch broke in the middle for an “Inside SNL” segment, and the cast moved next door to a press conference where reporters quizzed them on why the sketch failed so terribly. It was a funny premise, with Jones saying, “Look, SNL knew what they was getting when they hired me,” and Chappelle commenting he hoped the wig he wore would make him the next David S. Pumpkins. Not a home run, but a funny diversion before sinking back into the election. 
The next sketch showed Vanessa Bayer talking to children about politics (in a set-up resembling those of Beck Bennett’s pre- SNL AT&T commercials), asking what they knew about Donald Trump. The kids say things like “he’s funny,” and “he’s a bully,” until the scene cuts to a African-American girl who says, “He unleashed racism and xenophobia. We now return to dark ages of white presidents. Also, my dad said that Donald Trump will stop and frisk my cat. We have a black cat. His name’s Pussy.” It’s little surprise when we see that her father is Chappelle, who picks her up saying, “Sounds like someones dropping some truth.” The sketch fades out, leaving the phrase, “Our children are watching” against a black screen. 
The last few sketches include the return of McKinnon’s “Last Call” sketch, with Chappelle as her barfly companion, including the requisite sloppy make-out as bartender Kenan Thompson washes his eyes out with bleach. Next comes a short film mockumentary about Leslie Jones having a backstage relationship with Kyle Mooney , who is a virgin here, with the entire cast and crew somehow involved. Even Lorne Michaels makes an appearance, saying, “I don’t usually get involved in cast relationships, but I think it’s important for Kyle to lose his virginity.” The night’s final sketch finds Chappelle hosting a guy’s football hang at his mother’s house, where it turns out he lives, and having his mother (Jones) breastfeed him . 
All in all, at a bizarre and trying time, SNL came through. 
The show returns next week with host Kristen Wiig, and musical guest The xx.

thread.title: 'Making a Murderer' subject Steven Avery cleared a big legal hurdle in potentially proving his innocence
thread.title_full: 'Making a Murderer' subject Steven Avery cleared a big legal hurdle in potentially proving his innocence

posts.author: Jethro Nededog
posts.title: 'Making a Murderer' subject Steven Avery cleared a big legal hurdle in potentially proving his innocence
posts.text:
print 
"Making a Murderer" subject Steven Avery. Netflix 
"Making a Murderer" subject Steven Avery's attorney Kathleen Zellner announced that they have just cleared a major legal hurdle in potentially proving his innocence. 
Back in August, Zellner filed a motion to carry out tests on the case evidence in Wisconsin. Now nearly three months later, the tests can finally move forward. 
" Agreed Testing Order entered on Monday for Steven Avery," tweeted Zellner, who hopes that this closer look at the evidence will prove that at least some of it was planted . 
Agreed Testing Order entered on Monday for Steven Avery. #MakingAMurderer — Kathleen Zellner (@ZellnerLaw) November 12, 2016 
According to Uproxx , that means the scope of Zellner's proposed testing has been decided. That requires an agreement between Avery's legal team and the prosecutors in Manitowoc, Wisconsin, where in 2007 Steven Avery was convicted of the murder of Teresa Halbach — a trial covered by Netflix's hit "Making a Murderer." 
Specifics on the tests will be revealed after Zellner files the order on Monday and it becomes available to the public. 
What we do know is that Zellner's original motion included requests to test the keys to victim Teresa Halbach's Toyota Rav4; various parts of the Rav4, including the hood latch where police found Avery's DNA; purple underwear discovered in the Avery scrap yard; and all previously collected swabs from the trial, including blood that Avery's lawyers have argued came from a vial of Avery's blood that was held by the police. 
Avery and his nephew, Brendan Dassey, were both found guilty of the 2005 murder of Halbach. A judge overturned Dassey's conviction in August , but Wisconsin prosecutors are fighting the decision .

thread.title: How Lorelai And Emily's Relationship Will Change During The New Gilmore Girls Episodes
thread.title_full: How Lorelai And Emily's Relationship Will Change During The New Gilmore Girls Episodes

posts.title: How Lorelai And Emily's Relationship Will Change During The New Gilmore Girls Episodes
posts.text:
By jessica rawden 26 minutes ago 
Gilmore Girls is coming to Netflix in just a couple of weeks, and if you'd like to go into the series with a fresh perspective, now is a great time to hop to another article! 
Throughout the history of Gilmore Girls , we've seen Lorelei and Emily Gilmore make some breakthroughs as they have both struggled to try and understand the lifestyles they've each chosen and the choices and sacrifices they've each made. However, by the end of the original WB/CW series, Emily and Lorelei were still not 100% on the same page and still dealt with problems in their relationship. However, it looks like Emily and Lorelei's relationship will be changing when Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life hits the schedule. Here's what lead actress Lauren Graham had to say about the revival series : 
The healing that happens between Lorelai and Emily is such a long time coming. And because Richard's absence is such a big part of our story, it really meant a lot to me to grow their relationship a little bit. 
If you've been keeping tabs on the Gilmore Girls revival, you may already know that Gilmore Girls has plans to address Edward Herrmann's death. The actor passed away back in 2014, and as such, will not be a part of the revival. Since Rory's Grandpa and Lorelei's father was such an important part of the series, it makes sense that the show would at least touch on the character's death, and we've already heard a little bit about how Gilmore Girls plans to bring up that particular plotline. We also know the death in the family will bring up thoughts regarding the main characters' own feelings of mortality. 
Now, however, it looks as if Richard's death is going to have a profound affect on the series in other ways. Lauren Graham told TV Line that her relationship with her mother would also be affected by the death of her dad, and it seems like that should mostly be a good thing. Although we should note that Graham clarified things will only change "a little bit," so I think we should also expect some passionate arguments and even a few barbs will be exchanged through the four-episode series. Hopefully, all in all, the two women will end up closer to being on the same page than ever before. 
Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life will hit the schedule at 12:01 a.m. PT on Netflix. To find out what else the subscription streaming service has hitting the schedule here . In addition, take a look at what we know about Gilmore Girls ' upcoming revival with our guide to the new TV series. Subscribe

thread.title: 'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life' promises TV comfort food when we need it most | OregonLive.com
thread.title_full: 'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life' promises TV comfort food when we need it most | OregonLive.com

posts.author: Kristi Turnquist
posts.title: 'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life' promises TV comfort food when we need it most | OregonLive.com
posts.text:
When Netflix confirmed early this year that the much-loved TV show "Gilmore Girls" would be the latest in the streaming service's revivals, fans were thrilled. The timing seemed particularly tasty. "Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life," brings four 90-minute movies to Netflix, each one representing a different season of the year. The first chapter is "Winter," and all four will be available to stream on Netflix beginning Friday, Nov. 25. Netflix was clearly thinking a post-Thanksgiving binge weekend was perfect for "Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life," which picks up the story of single mother Lorelai Gilmore ( Lauren Graham ), and her daughter, Rory ( Alexis Bledel ), 10 years after we saw them last, when the series ended its seven-season run in 2007. Now, in the wake of one of the most stressful presidential elections in memory, "Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life" promises to offer comfort food in a way even Netflix didn't anticipate. For legions of "Gilmore Girl" devotees, the show brought a vision of domestic life that was both a snug fantasy and a breath-of-fresh-air reality. On the one hand, Lorelai and Rory Gilmore lived in the cozy imaginary town of Stars Hollow, Connecticut, where the buildings were quaint, and the locals endearingly quirky. Mother and daughter were best friends, who traded fast-talking, pop culture-laced banter but were there for each other in times of sorrow and heartbreak. It's true that Stars Hollow wasn't the most diverse place on earth, but in many other ways, it represented an escapist ideal, where everyone could stop in at Luke's Diner and enjoy a cup of coffee and a burger. Created by Amy Sherman-Palladino, "Gilmore Girls" was ahead of its time in its sympathetic portrayal of Lorelai, who got pregnant with Rory at age 16, and went out on her own, rebelling against her controlling, wealthy parents, Richard and Emily (played, respectively, by the late Edward Herrmann and Kelly Bishop ), declining to marry Rory's father, and living her own life in Stars Hollow. 
Over time, Lorelai builds a comfortable home for her and Rory, with Lorelai becoming an innkeeper, and Rory building her braniac skills, first at a ritzy prep school (tuition provided by Lorelai's parents), and later at Yale. Thanks to DVD sets, reruns and Netflix, the original "Gilmore Girls" has become a cross-generational favorite, a show mothers watch with daughters, and that families can enjoy without worrying about too many adults-only plot twists. 
It's that ongoing fandom that has made "Gilmore Girls" A Year in the Life" one of the most eagerly anticipated TV events of the year. 
All the single mothers who identified with Lorelai, the teenage girls who looked to Rory as a role model, and 'shippers obsessed with Lorelai and Rory's romantic lives are planning to devour the new episodes just as Lorelai and Rory scarfed down junk food on Gilmore movie nights. At a discussion of "Gilmore Girls: A Year in Life" during the summer Television Critics Association press tour, Sherman-Palladino acknowledged the show's lasting appeal. "I hear a lot of, like, 'My daughter wanted to go to Yale because of Rory," Sherman-Palladino said. "And she read books because of Rory.'" 
"Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life" will reflect some offscreen reality, with the death of actor Edward Herrmann. In the new episodes, Emily Gilmore, as well as her daughter and granddaughter, react to the loss of Richard Gilmore. But many other cast favorites will return, including Scott Patterson as Luke, diner-owner and – maybe? – the love of Lorelai's life; Melissa McCarthy, who played Lorelai's best friend, Sookie; David Sutcliffe as Rory's father, Christopher; Liza Weil as Rory's old classmate, Paris; and Rory's beaus, Jared Padalecki (Dean), Milo Ventimiglia (Jess) and Matt Czuchry (Logan.) And, now that Sherman-Palladino is back in control, she'll be able to write the famous final four words that she always knew would end the show. Fans are speculating wildly about what those words might be. Since Graham has said the words are spoken by Lorelai and Rory, a popular guess is something along the lines of, "I'm pregnant," and "Me, too." Once the episodes are streaming on Netflix, of course, social media will spoil the surprise, something Sherman-Palladino regrets. At the TCA press tour, Sherman-Palladino said that, contrary to her request, Netflix will stream all four "Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life" episodes on Nov. 25, instead of spacing them out. "It was my hope to put them our separately," Sherman-Palladino said, because "I am a thousand," and still likes having some time elapse between watching episodes, instead of the full-steam-ahead binge model. 
"And also because it's such a journey and it's such a build to the last four words," Sherman-Palladino said. "And because we live in an age where I knew people were going to go right to the last four words and then put it on the Internet, and possibly spoil it for people who are going to take the journey." 
However "Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life" ends, it's likely to again provide a respite from arguments about politics and protests, or any of the other issues that make the world beyond Stars Hollow feel like a tough place to be right now. 
Months ago, during the TCA summer press tour, Graham touched on just that warm-and-fuzzy aspect of the "Gilmore Girls" world as a reason for its enduring popularity. 
"It's extremely comforting," Graham said, "in a world that is lacking comfort." 
— Kristi Turnquist

thread.title: ‘Making A Murderer’s’ Brendan Dassey Released From Prison
thread.title_full: ‘Making A Murderer’s’ Brendan Dassey Released From Prison

posts.author: Danielle Canada
posts.title: ‘Making A Murderer’s’ Brendan Dassey Released From Prison
posts.text:
Brendan Dassey Released If you’ve watched Netflix’s “Making A Murderer” then you’re well aware of Brendan Dassey, the nephew of Steven Avery who was “recklessly coerced” into a confession.
Well now at 27, Brendan has been released in the rape and murder case of Teresa Halbach.
The Daily Mail reports: 
A federal judge has ordered that Brendan Dassey – whose case was featured in the Netflix documentary Making a Murderer – be released from prison immediately.
A federal magistrate judge ruled in August that investigators tricked Dassey into confessing he helped his uncle, Avery, rape, kill and mutilate Halbach, a photographer, in 2005.
Dassey, who turned 27 Wednesday, was 16 at the time. The magistrate ordered that Dassey be freed unless prosecutors appealed or decided to retry him.
Dassey was sentenced to life in prison in 2007.
His uncle Steven Avery is still incarcerated for Halbach’s death.

A lawyer for Avery recently shared however that they’re hoping to get some evidence tested in hopes of showing that it was planted.
Agreed Testing Order entered on Monday for Steven Avery. #MakingAMurderer 
— Kathleen Zellner (@ZellnerLaw) November 12, 2016 

What do YOU think about the latest “Making A Murderer” update???
